Question: I don't think my university or college is doing enough: a) to prevent the spread of coronavirus, or b) to support students in the current situation. What should I do?
Answer:
Students with concerns should first raise these with their university, college or other higher education provider.

Students can escalate complaints with the [Office of the Independent Adjudicator](https://www.oiahe.org.uk/) (OIA) once they have exhausted the complaints procedure at their higher education provider.

The OfS does not have a direct role in individual student complaints, but students or organisations or members of the public may [tell us](https://www.officeforstudents.org.uk/contact/complaints-and-notifications/) about any issue that may be of regulatory interest to us.

The OfS will then consider this as part of our overall regulation of the provider.

Question: What support should students with care experience, refugees, estranged students and other vulnerable groups expect from their university or college?
Answer:
The government has asked universities and colleges to make sure that certain groups of students get the support that they need during the coronavirus outbreak. These include

*   international students

*   care leavers

*   estranged students

*   disabled students

*   students who live with people in high risk groups.

Universities and colleges should ensure that the following support is in place for these groups:

*   Guaranteed appropriate accommodation. If it is safe and feasible vulnerable students should have the option to remain in their accommodation. If students are required to move, universities and colleges should make sure that those students can get the practical assistance that they need.

*   Continued access to established financial support, and to immediate hardship funding if necessary. Where universities and colleges are likely to be impacted by staff shortages or office closures this may need to be paid to vulnerable students in advance.

*   Practical support to access food, medical and cleaning supplies.

*   Ongoing access to a first point of contact for student queries and concerns and for proactive wellbeing support.

*   Ongoing access to student support networks, mental health support and academic support where required.

If you are concerned that your university or college is not providing enough support for these groups of students, please raise it with them in the first instance.

Students can escalate complaints with the [Office of the Independent Adjudicator](https://www.oiahe.org.uk/) once they have exhausted the complaints procedure at their higher education provider.

Question: What mental health support can I expect from my university or college during the coronavirus pandemic?
Answer:
The OfS recognises that this is an anxious time for many. Universities and colleges should be providing clear and accessible information about mental health and wellbeing support for their full student population.

This includes continuing to provide appropriate support for students who have an existing mental health condition that they have declared to their university or college.

Many universities and colleges have been quick to respond to the emerging and challenging situation including through moving support services such as counselling and mentoring to phone or online.

If you have concerns about your mental health, it is important to get in touch with your university or college.

For more information about other organisations which may be able to support you, please see our [mental health resources for students](https://www.officeforstudents.org.uk/advice-and-guidance/student-wellbeing-and-protection/mental-health/resources-for-students/) webpage.

Question: What should universities and colleges be doing to help students to continue with courses and assessments?
Answer:
The OfS have published [guidance for universities and colleges](https://www.officeforstudents.org.uk/publications/guidance-for-providers-about-quality-and-standards-during-coronavirus-pandemic/) about how the OfS will regulate quality and standards during this period of disruption. This states that universities and colleges should make all reasonable efforts:

*   to enable students to complete their studies

*   for achievement to be reliably assessed

*   for qualifications to be awarded securely

*   to enable a fair and robust admissions process for entrants to courses in 2020-21.

Universities and colleges can decide how best to do this based on the context they are working in but it is important that they consider how all students are affected, particularly those who might not be able to access remote learning for any reason.

If your university or college makes any changes to your contractual terms and conditions because they are changing the way that they deliver your course or award your qualification, they should contact you to tell you:

*   what the changes are, before they take effect

*   the reasons for the changes

*   the impact the changes are likely to have

*   the options available to you if you want to avoid the changes (without you being adversely affected).

If you are not getting the information you need, contact your university or college course team or support services to ask for advice. You can make a complaint to your university or college, or an academic appeal, about the arrangements put in place during the pandemic.

If you are still not satisfied, you may be able to make a complaint to the Office of the Independent Adjudicator (OIA). Check their [coronavirus guidance for students](https://www.oiahe.org.uk/students/coronavirus-faq-for-students/).

Question: I am a degree apprentice. How will my studies and assessment be affected?
Answer:
The [Institute for Apprenticeships and Technical Education](https://www.instituteforapprenticeships.org/covid-19-information-regarding-apprenticeships/response-to-covid-19/) has stated that:

Every effort should continue to be made to ensure that apprentices can continue with their apprenticeship, and be assessed in accordance with current EPA (End-Point Assessment) plan and EQA (External Quality Assurance) requirements if possible.  Where this is not possible, providers should first consider whether it is appropriate to extend the apprenticeship in order to reschedule the EPA.

You should contact your training provider for more information on how this may affect your apprenticeship.

The government has provided [guidance](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-apprenticeship-programme-response) for students, employers and training providers in response to Covid-19. It outlines new, temporary measures being introduced to support apprentices to be able to complete their apprenticeship, pause or continue their apprenticeship and to support training providers during this time.

Question: A university or college recently switched my offer from conditional to unconditional. Is this now in jeopardy?
Answer:
The university or college that you applied to should be able to confirm details of any existing offer that you have from them, and there will be greater certainty for all applicants once universities and colleges have had time to understand how the process for qualifications will work this year.

It is really important to remember that you do not need to accept your offer right now. You will be able to make a more informed choice about all available opportunities once the pause on offer-making has ended and will have plenty of time to make your decision once you know all of the options available to you.

Check the [latest UCAS deadlines](https://www.ucas.com/undergraduate/after-you-apply/coronavirus-covid-19/what-does-mean-your-application) on their website, or if you are applying directly to a university or college contact their admissions department.
